title: Definition of a Bar Graph
text: Bar graphs show different bars that are separated from one another, separating categorical data into their categories. The bars are rectangles that can be horizontal or vertical. The four states that begin with a "W" are Washington, West Virginia, Wisconsin, and Wyoming.

title: Determining the Categories for the Bars
text: Since we're using vertical bars, our horizontal axis will list out the categories. Are the categories the states or the percents? Think about how we're separating the data into different groups. What are those groups?

title: Determining the Horizontal Axis
text: Knowing that the categories are states, which graph can we EXCLUDE?

subHints.title: Determining the Horizontal Axis
subHints.text: Which graph does not have states on the horizontal axis?

title: Correctness of Bins
text: From the three remaining graphs, Graph B, C, and D, we can determine next which ones use the accurate names for the states.

title: Correctness of Bins
text: Which graph does not use the correct names? In other words, which graph's chosen states are not the ones we want (all the states beginning with the letter "W")?

title: Correctness of Data Values for Each Bin
text: Now we're down to the final two: Graph B and Graph D. To determine which bar graph is correct, we must determine which one uses the correct data points. For instance, the percent for Washington should be $$25.5\%$$, for West Virginia should be $$32.5\%$$, for Wisconsin should be $$26.3\%$$, and for Wyoming should be $$25.1\%$$.

title: Correctness of Data Values for Each Bin
text: Which of Graph B and Graph D is the correct graph? Which graph uses the correct data points listed above?
